pr_title: CB-10095 Subnet selection for public gateway endpoint

timeline.message:
CB-10095 Subnet selection for public gateway endpoint

Adds new logic to create a public load balancer to act as a public gateway to
the Knox endpoints in an otherwise private system. Logic will be triggered if
the "publicEndpointAccessGateway" flag in the environment request is set to
ENABLED, and the tenant has the new CDP_PUBLIC_ENDPOINT_ACCESS_GATEWAY
entitlement.

A list of subnets to use for the public LB can optionally be provided as part
of the environment creation request. If provided, any private subnets in the
list will be discarded, and a public subnet in the same AZ as the selected stack
subnet will be used. If the endpoint subnets aren't explicitly provided, the
subnets provided for environment creation are used instead. If public subnets in
the appropriate availability zones are not provided, creation will fail
immediately.

Tested with unit tests and by running CB locally with hardcoded API fields to
verify cloud resources were created and configured appropriately.

timeline.bodyText: Should we still use the selectedAZ here? The selectedAZ can be coming from the network request, but the user maybe explicitly specifying the subnet to use for the endpoint gateway anyways if provided. I was thinking that the provided getGatewayEndpointSubnetMetas will always take precedence.
timeline.author: enis

replies.bodyText: I'd argue against the getGatewayEndpointSubnetMetas taking precedence, since their use case is very limited vs. the private subnets which are used more widely. But we do need to include the selected AZ, because the private and public subnets needs to be in the same AZ for the load balancer to work.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

timeline.bodyText:
Seeing the name of this function together with the one below, I was just confused why we are having a check for both a Set (as in HashSet) and a List check. It turns out it is a check for existence.
Maybe we can merge the List vs non-list cases to simplify. If there is only 1 subnet, then it is a list of 1.
timeline.author: enis

replies.bodyText: I can rename the function to make it more clear. I don't really want to change the methods themselves because they were written following the same pattern as is used for the environment subnet list.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

replies.bodyText: Changed this method name to containsEndpointGatewaySubnet.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

timeline.bodyText: Should this check be a subset check rather than equals() check? We can have env with 3 subnets, but endpoint gateway with 1 subnet, no?
timeline.author: enis

replies.bodyText: No, we can't. The load balancer needs subnets in the same AZs as all the EC2 instances it's routing to. So if our private subnets are in az-1, az-2, and az-3, and our public subnets are in az-1 and az-2, then if an EC2 instance is created in az-3 it's completely inaccessible to the load balancer. In order to prevent that possibility, we require the users to provide both private and public subnets in all the same AZs, which is what this check is doing here.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

replies.bodyText:
My understanding is that the initial set of subnets given at the time of the env creation can contain more subnets than actually gets used for DL/DH instances (like subnets for dwx, liftie, etc). In DH you can select which subnet to use, but apparently not for DL?
Maybe this is fine, as long as somebody from CB who knows the subnet selection logic takes a look at it.
replies.author: enis

replies.bodyText: That's true. Not every subnet in the lists being processed here will be used. Which is really why I have this logic. At this stage I don't know which of the subnets will be selected, so to make sure there won't be any hiccups in the eventual subnet selection logic I just make sure that we have subnets with matching AZs here and fail immediately if not.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

timeline.bodyText: same here.
timeline.author: enis

timeline.bodyText: so it doesn't a converter anymore as it creates loadbalancers. I liked it when it returned the loadbalancer instead of adding to a list in the parameters.
timeline.author: lacikaaa

replies.bodyText: It converting from CloudLoadBalancer to AwsLoadBalancer. So in that sense it was always creating an instance of AwsLoadBalancer and setting its properties based on the properties of CloudLoadBalancer. That piece of the logic hasn't really changed. I will update it to return the AwsLoadBalancer and add it to the list in the parent method instead of here.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

timeline.author: lacikaaa

private final Set<String> instanceIds = new HashSet<>();

If we can't remove them please create a followup jira to remove them in the next release, if you haven't created one already. thanks

because of continuous deployment, we need to keep backward and forward compatibility
so a follow-up jira is indeed needed to remove these (there is another field, below).

replies.bodyText: Right. Originally I had deleted them, but I had a talk with Arpad about the compatibility requirements and that led me to adding them back and marking them deprecated. I'll open another JIRA to clean these methods up once this PR is in.

replies.bodyText:
I had the idea that the network settings that are triggering the new logic wouldn't be set unless the entitlement is enabled. So we can check for the existence of those settings as an implicit check to see if the entitlement is enabled.
Thinking on it now, I realize I don't think we're checking the entitlement when setting those settings for CLI requests. (It will be checked for the UI changes to toggle these settings, which are in progress.) I can add some new logic to check the entitlement when both the environment and stack creation requests are received, and make sure to unset those fields if the entitlement isn't enabled. That should prevent any of the subsequent logic from triggering. I'll go ahead and do a check whenever we're setting the feature related fields in the various objects as well.
replies.author: hreeve-cloudera

replies.bodyText: I've added the entitlement check anywhere we're setting the endpoint gateway related fields. If the original environment request has those fields set but the entitlement is disabled, then it will unset them before processing the request. I also added a lot of unit tests to verify the behavior when the entitlement is disabled and enabled.

CB-10095 Subnet selection for public gateway endpoint

Adds new logic to create a public load balancer to act as a public gateway to
the Knox endpoints in an otherwise private system. Logic will be triggered if
the "publicEndpointAccessGateway" flag in the environment request is set to
ENABLED, and the tenant has the new CDP_PUBLIC_ENDPOINT_ACCESS_GATEWAY
entitlement.

A list of subnets to use for the public LB can optionally be provided as part
of the environment creation request. If provided, any private subnets in the
list will be discarded, and a public subnet in the same AZ as the selected stack
subnet will be used. If the endpoint subnets aren't explicitly provided, the
subnets provided for environment creation are used instead. If public subnets in
the appropriate availability zones are not provided, creation will fail
immediately.

Tested with unit tests and by running CB locally with hardcoded API fields to
verify cloud resources were created and configured appropriately.
